intro: Peucedanum ruthenicum var. tauricum, commonly known as the Tauric cow parsley, is a perennial herb native to the Caucasus region. It belongs to the Apiaceae family, characterized by its aromatic foliage and umbellate flowers. The plant typically grows to a height of 60-100 cm, featuring finely divided, fern-like leaves. Its flowers are white to pale green, arranged in flat-topped clusters, and bloom in late spring to early summer. It thrives in moist, well-drained soils and is often found in forested areas or along stream banks.
